Award.AwardTitle: Renewal of Information Assurance Excellence Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The CybercorpsÂ®: Scholarship for Service (SFS) program at California State University San Bernardino (CSUSB) promotes cybersecurity excellence through a dynamic curriculum, unique applied learning requirements, and a diverse student population. The curriculum is designed around the needs of government organizations seeking well-qualified students. While many SFS programs across the country focus on policy; management of technology; or secure programming, design and development; CSUSB has created a curriculum that combines the elements of various programs, including some elements of national security studies. A typical CSUSB Cybercorps student is well versed in cyber security policy, tactics, threat analysis, counter intelligence, networking, database, offensive and defensive hacking and penetration testing, and forensics, all with applied professional experiences. All SFS Cybercorps students are challenged in a variety of ways including SCADA security; cyber defense and forensics competitions; and extracurricular activities such as social engineering, physical security, and intelligence gathering. CSUSB's service area is richly populated with residents from diverse ethnic backgrounds, including those groups that are currently underrepresented in cybersecurity field. Most CSUSB Cybercorps students are first generation minority students, transferring from community colleges, often from low-income and disadvantaged backgrounds, coming to college less academically and socially prepared than their non-first generation peers. From tutoring to etiquette to professional behavior, CSUSB places great emphasis on ensuring this diverse student cohort (50% Hispanic, and 43% female) learns the skills necessary to successfully obtain and retain professional employment. The CSUSB Cybercorps program's 98% placement rate supports the federal cybersecurity mission.

POR.DRECONTENT:
California State University, San Bernardino (CSUSB) has offered the CyberCorps: Scholarship for Service (SFS) program to send students to work in cybersecurity positions in the federal government. The program is part of a large-scale response to help build a qualified cybersecurity workforce for the nation. In addition to sending students into the federal workforce, the program also makes a concentrated effort to serve minorities and women, both underrepresented in IT professions. These efforts have led to increased diversity in cyber security programs across the board.

Students in the program received academic support and mentoring, and the retention rate for students in the program is 100%, barring extenuating circumstances. In addition to participating in workshops and competitions, students were required to complete at least 50 lab hours per quarter to build their knowledge and skills in information assurance and computer security. All of the students took classes required for their cohort, and regular meetings helped to promote an effective learning environment. The design of the program ensures that students have access to academic support resources on campus.

The goals of the program were met and often exceeded: 1) Recruited four cohorts, each with 8 highly qualified graduate and undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds; 2) provided ongoing academic support and mentoring to the Scholars that resulted in a 100% annual retention rate, with the exception of extenuating circumstances; 3) to facilitate the ongoing application of knowledge and skills, Scholars participated in one workshop per quarter and two technology competitions per year and engaged in 50 hours per quarter of applied activities in the IASMC Research Lab; 4) 100% of the Scholars were successfully placed in internships; 5) 100% of scholarship recipients graduated with a bachelor’s or master’s degree and transitioned into the federal cyber service; 6) Established processes and procedures to ensure the efficient and effective management of the program.

The evaluation of the SFS program gave a few possible strategies to make the program even more effective in producing its intended objectives in relation to tailored programming, time management, and workshops. Highlighted in the evaluation for their effectiveness were implementation, environment, and overall outcomes of the program. Students have access to support and various opportunities through the program, including cybersecurity certifications, employment opportunities, and effective preparation for careers in cybersecurity.

Broader Impact: CSUSB is a Minority Serving Institution and a Hispanic Serving Institution – – 42.3% of its students are Hispanics, 14.1% are African American, 8.4% Asian and 1% Native American (IPEDS). SFS recruitment efforts targeted attracting a diverse range of applicants from CSUSB and community colleges, many of whom were students from underrepresented groups. The Scholars were diverse on both gender and ethnicity. The majority of the Scholars were Hispanics and 43% were female.

The program gave students access to opportunities that prepared them for federal employment in cybersecurity positions. Students received academic support and mentoring in order to ensure their needs were met, particularly as many students at CSUSB are first generation and minority students, some from low-income and disadvantaged backgrounds. The program has made every effort to serve the wide range of scholars interested in growing the cybersecurity workforce.
